title: How influential was Egyptian philosophy on the Greeks? - Quora
tags: Ancient and Modern Task of Philosophy

response.answer_text: They didn’t go to study in Egypt, but the first Greek philosophers were undoubtedly influenced by Egyptian mathematicians and philosophers and acknowledged as much. It’s important to remember that in the ancient world Greeks did not only live in what is now Greece - they settled everywhere, including quite a few places in Egypt, so quite a few ancient Egyptian philosophers were probably Greek. Your friend lists the philosophers in the wrong order - Pythagoras - who did visit Egypt and may have studied with Egyptian philosophers - died before Socrates was born and Plato and Aristotle, the first philosophers whose work survives in large parts, were a generation later and studied earlier Greek philosophers without bothering with Egyptian philosophy, even if they could have come across it. The reason ancient Egyptian philosophy isn’t much mentioned is because hardly any of it survived. Not much early Greek - preSocratic - philosophy survives either. Most of what there is consists of fragments and short passages quoted by later philosophers. There’s a book by Jonathan Barnes, Early Greek Philosophy, containing translations of nearly all that is extant with a commentary, and that’s about 330 pages long.

Dear friend, your question has alot to do with my life’s research as a painter, and a Greek, on cultural identity. SO I hope you find my answer interesting. First of all I would like to comment on some of the presupositions of your question. You presuppose that greek culture is european. Are you sure that’s true? You also presuppose that roots and early influences define a culture. Which is what your real question should be. It’s not your fault of course, it is a very strong misconception that is rampant in the west, so strong it is seldomly questioned and is the cause of the previous beleif that greek culture is western. But greek culture and greek philosophers did not infuence the west only, the influence is strong in the east as well. The persian philosopher Avikenna was an Aristotelian scholar and Sufi mystical schools are basicly platonic, to name a few. Not to mention the influence that Alexander the great’s empire had to the east that reached as far as india. Ancient greek medicine is still practised in some of these areas. So if your thesis is true, since east and west have a common root or influence they must be the same. But this is obviously NOT the case. You would get more accurate results however in determining cultural identity if you focused more on the FRUITS and less on the ROOTS. So yes Plato, Solon and Pythagoras are noted to have studied in Egypt (not Socratis or Aristotle though) but even if all the greek philosophers HAD studied in Egypt as your friend thinks, it wouldn’t prove anything as far as cultural identity goes. And the same goes for the Eurocentric question since greek culture is not western nor Eastern. This last statement will probably shock many people, but this is what the study of the FRUIT show without a shadow of a doubt. Lets take the art these cultures produce for example. The art does NOT LIE, but you must understand it’s language. Are you familiar with Plato’s analogy of the devided line? Have you noticed that Egyptian, African and Eastern art focuses more on the abstract and geometric? Well if you see in that a beleif that the Eternal is the real reality, according to Plato you would be correct. Now lets visit the real origins of western culture: The renaissance. Do you notice how the focus here is on the visual sences? Again if you see in that the beleif that the world of time and history is the real reality…according to plato you would be right again. Now look at an Orthodox Icon (look at a Panselinos Icon for example), it merges these two worlds together: the geometric eternal with the temporality of the sences, it does what Hellenistic portraiture does, but in a more apparent way. The Orthodox peoples and states of today are the real inheriters of this merging of the Eternal and Temporal but because of western colonialism haven’t managed yet to express it in a coherent cultural form. And part of this colonial ideology is the beleif that the ROOT is what defines a culture. I hope this helped.

There is a trilogy of books, called “Black Athena” by Bernal that argues that Ancient Greeks were far more influenced by the Egyptians that Westerners want to admit. Most scientists dismiss it. Black Athena - Wikipedia Thomas McEvilley concluded in 2002 that while Bernal's "analysis of earlier periods of anti-Semitic attitude in regard to ancient Near Eastern culture may remain valuable, his attempt...to derive Greek philosophy from Africa seems so glaringly unsupported by evidence that it is likely to pass without leaving a trace

Exactly as Konstantinos Konstantinides says, widespread Egyptian influence on Greece is a hypothesis that has been largely dismissed by modern historians and anthropologists. That doesn’t mean there has been no influence whatsoever, but the afrocentric claim the Classical Greek culture is entirely derived from Egyptian has been dismissed, and your friend isn’t even paraphrasing the hypothesis correctly. The actual “Black Athena” hypothesis rests on a lot of skimpy evidence, such as some Greek writers revering Egypt for being an older civilization, and superficial similarities between the Greek and Egyptian religions (when the Greek religion can more accurately be traced to Proto-Indo-European, not Afro-Semitic).

I mean, none of those people ‘went to Egypt to study’ in the sense that they went to a university and were handed down a set of doctrines. They may have been aware to different degrees of what the smart guys in Egypt were saying. And they didn’t “get their philosophies from Ancient Egypt,” anymore than you appropriated your sentence structure from Shakespeare. Both speaking English, one first, but providing different content. Both Greeks and Egyptians did ‘philosophy’ insofar as they pondered some fundamental questions. Their answers were each their own. There is historical debate about how extensively Greek philosophers had read or encountered Egyptian philosophy - which did pre-date Greek philosophy. It didn’t have the same content, conclusions, or metaphysics. I’d say your friends statement would be equivalent to this: “Modern rap producers have an afrocentric bias, focusing on African American rappers, when a lot of the African Americans got their flow from Blondie’s 1980 song, Rapture.’”
